text:
- [Rajesh] Hello, my
name is Rajesh Francis

and I'm a Senior Analytics
Customer Experience Specialist
at AWS.

Amazon Redshift Serverless
is a serverless option

of Amazon Redshift with
all existing functionality
and offers a simple user experience.

It scales dynamically
based on incoming workloads

and you pay only for the
compute capacity you use.
In this demo, I will demonstrate

how Amazon Redshift Serverless
intelligently scales

based on incoming workloads
for best performance
and show you how you can estimate cost
for the capacity you use.

I have run some sample
workloads simulating heavy usage

with hundreds of users
and thousands of queries.
This chart is based on the actual workload

and shows how how Amazon
Redshift Serverless

compute capacity has scaled
based on incoming queries.
Let's spend a minute to understand this
using a quick side dashboard.

This shows relationship
between query count in blue,
execution time in green and the RPU,

which is Redshift Processing
Unit in orange colors.

The RPU starts off at zero and
starts to scale automatically
to default RPU of 128,
then to 768 as more queries come in

and all the way to 1408 to
process the peak workload
which is over 20,000 queries.

Again, as you can see, query
count in blue shows 20,410
and RPU in orange shows 1408.
And then the RPU goes back down to zero
when there are no queries.

But as you can see, even with
the peak workload of queries,

the query execution time
shown in green color
remains consistent.

This shows Redshift
Serverless is able to scale

to process incoming
queries as they come in
to deliver consistent, fast performance
even for the most demanding workloads.
And then the RPU goes back down to zero
when there are no workloads
and you pay only for the RPU seconds used.

Now let us see how cost is
calculated based on usage.
With Amazon Redshift Serverless,

you pay for compute
and storage separately.

You pay for the workloads
you run in RPU hours

on a per second basis with
a 60 second minimum charge
and you will not be charged for idle time,

which is when no queries
or workloads is running.

Comprehensive security
capabilities are included

and you do not pay separately
for concurrency scaling

or to query data in S3
using retro spectrum
because it is part of the RPU calculation
and the RPU itself could scale up or down
based on workloads.
As we just saw earlier in the dashboard,

Amazon Redshift Serverless
automatically provisions
and scales resources up or down

based on workload variability
to meet unpredictable demands.

So you don't have to worry
about overprovisioning
or underprovisioning resources.

For storage, you are charged
a fixed gigabyte per month
based on S3 pricing.

The data you ingest
into Redshift Serverless
is persisted in Redshift Managed Storage,
which is a combination of local SSD and S3

and is available even when
RPU goes down to zero.

Amazon Redshift Serverless
can give you the best price

for performance for
various types of workloads:
variable, unpredictable workloads,
periodic workloads with idle time

and steady state workloads
where there is consistent usage
for a period of time.

Our recommendation is to execute
a representative workload
for your peak and non-peak time periods
and calculate the average compute usage

and that average can be used
as a base RPU for Serverless.

You can also monitor both RPU
capacity and compute usage
from the monitoring section
of Amazon Redshift Serverless console.

Here you see the RPU capacity
scale from zero to 128
for normal workload

and to 400 for heavy
workload and back to zero
when there is really no workload.

And similarly, you have the
compute usage in seconds
in the dashboard as well.

This metric is also
available in CloudWatch
under AWS Redshift Serverless.

And you can look at
metrics with no dimensions

and review compute capacity
and compute seconds.

You can also change the
base RPU capacity to scale
beyond 128

under the Limits tab in the
Serverless configuration

and Serverless will automatically
scale to that default RPU.

Compute seconds is the
accumulated compute unit consumed

and it is calculated by
multiplying compute capacity

times the number of seconds
the compute is used.

This value is stored in
Sys Serverless Usage Table
in 30 minute intervals.

Now if we take this line item
as an example for 2022-2-04
between 2105 and 2135,
total compute seconds is 1133.

Then to calculate the
total cost for this period,

you can convert the seconds,
which is 133 to hours,
1133 to hours, which will be 0.315

and cost of compute in
US East to one region
is 50 cents per hour,

so the cost of compute for
the time period is 15 cents
for 0.315 hours.
You can use the SQL statements below
to calculate the total compute cost
and the total storage cost based on data
in the Sys Serverless Usage Table
and this aggregate's the cost by day.

In this demo, I showed you
how Amazon Redshift Serverless

scales based on the
demands of your workload
to provide consistent performance

and how you can calculate
cost for compute and storage
you actually use.

We encourage you to try
Amazon Redshift Serverless

and you can get more
details using this link.
Thank you.
